section.title: Introduction to Non-Level Payment Annuities
section.p: Before we look at our examples of payments in geometric or arithmetic progression, we are going to look at the general case to get a feel for it. If we have an annuity-immediate with a total of n payments, and the payment at time t is K_t, with an appropriate effective interest rate \iota, then the present value is:
There is little we can do in general in this case, outside of calculating the sums.
Let's work with this a little using some exercises.

statement.p: An annuity has K_1 = 100, K_2 = 200, and K_3 = 350 with \iota = 6.5\%. Find the value at time t = 7.
An annuity has K_1 = 50, K_2 = 100, K_3 = 575, and K_4 = 200 with \iota = 3\%. Find the value at time t=-3.
There are five payments in an annuity immediate: K_1 =700, K_2 = 550, K_4 = 600, and K_5 = 900. The effective periodic interest rate is \iota = 5\%, and the accumulated value is 3430.99. Find K_3.

introduction.p: A bond includes a level-payment annuity-immediate (the payments are called coupon payments) with an additional payment (called the redemption amount) added to the final payment of the annuity. For now, we will assume the payments are annual (usually they are semiannual), and therefore the number of payments is also the term. The price is the present value of everything in sight.

task.p: A bond includes 10 annual coupon payments of 25 and its price, at an effective annual interest rate of \iota = 3\%, is 957.35. Find the redemption amount.
A bond has annual coupon payments of 60, a redemption amount of 1200. At an effective annual interest rate of \iota = 4.5\%, the bond is priced at 1,278.05. Find the term.
